header.title: The Scroll of Set (Issue Number 46, Volume IV-10)

central_thesis: The Temple of Set is an evolving organization dedicated to facilitating individual Setian magical evolution, known as Setamorphosis, through direct communion with the Set-entity. This process is supported by a structured hierarchy, communal gatherings (Conclaves), and strategic initiatives (like the First Foundation) aimed at navigating external realities while fostering internal, unique divinity among its Initiates.

structure_content.summary: This article reports on the successful Set-I Conclave, highlighting its role in establishing a stronger bond and understanding among Initiates, uniting the Order of Set, and providing opportunities for direct magical communication with the Set-entity through rituals. It emphasizes the Temple’s administrative and magical functions, including the Recognition of a new Master of the Temple, Magister Lynn Norton.

This section defines 'Ipsissimus' as 'His very own self' or 'he who is himself the most,' a unique initiatory state of being recognized by the Temple of Set, exemplified by Michael A. Aquino. It describes the emotional significance of this recognition, symbolized by a gold and silver pentagram medallion, and frames it as a testament to the Temple’s and individual's evolution towards intellectual activity and 'true divinity'.

This report details the high attendance and organizational success of the first international Set-I Conclave, involving extensive travel by 32 Setians. It outlines the planning phases, acknowledges key contributors, and describes significant events such as a III°+ working, a simultaneous I°/II° ritual, an all-member conclave ritual, and the Recognition of Master Lynn A. Norton.

This section lists the key topics presented during the Conclave meetings: the First Foundation (1F) mission, the meaning of the degrees, the 'pyramid' communication structure, Setian protocol, and 'Food Combining and Compatibility of Foods.' These discourses were recorded for future use in Temple publications.

A personal reflection on the profound impact of the Set-I Conclave, emphasizing the unique 'special quality' and commitment of Setians to their individual essence. It touches upon the feeling of connection among geographically dispersed Initiates and places the Temple of Set's work, particularly the 1F, as vital for personal freedom and navigating future societal challenges.

This article explores the authentic meaning of 'Brothers and Sisters' within the Setian context, contrasting it with mundane or superficial usage. It highlights the real love and empathy felt among Setians and offers personal photographs from the Conclave as a token of affection and a way to share the joy of the 'magnificent Elect'.

A short, poetic piece describing a magical experience involving a glowing pentagram, conceived as a portal, and the immersion of the self into its center, linking it to the Sacred Cut and the presence of Xem.

Reflections on the post-conclave experience, describing the 'post-conclave blues' and the difficulty of returning to mundane reality after intense magical bonding. It mentions the recognition of a new Master and two new Adepts, underscoring the richness and evolution within the Temple.

A poetic vision portraying a deep connection between the individual, the Setian community ('the people who seek me'), and the spiritual landscape of Xem. It speaks of nurturing future generations, teaching the awakened, and transcending limitations to 'Xeper ir Xem' through open 'gates'.
An announcement by High Priest Ronald Barrett that the Set-I Conclave will become a yearly event, open to the entire Temple, held at XemSet near the North Solstice.

A report on a III°+ meeting at XemSet, detailing discussions on By-Laws amendments, Bettye Fischer's resignation, Certificate of Ordination design, and the recognition of Ipsissimus Michael Aquino. It provides a vivid description of the ritual grounds and the ceremonial lighting of torches during a night outdoor working.

structure_content.chapter_title: [12] Set and God: The Power of Their Telesmic Images
structure_content.summary: This article discusses 'telesmic images' as mental constructs sustained by human energy. It argues that Set exists intrinsically, while 'God' is solely a human-created entity dependent on human thought. It asserts Setians are of a 'higher evolutionary order' with superior 'right-brain activity,' making their magical/mental power more potent than the collective energy of many 'God-believers,' emphasizing individual attainment over numbers.
A formal announcement of Robertt W. Neilly's recognition as a Priest of Set III°, noting his joining the Temple in July 1977.

Provides historical, etymological, and astrological information for the months of August and September, including birthstones, Roman festivals, and associated Egyptian deities (Heru-xuti/Harmachis for August, Thoth for September).

A detailed narrative of the travel and experiences of Setians attending Set-I, highlighting the magical nature of their journey despite challenges like flight disruptions, severe weather, and difficult logistics. It emphasizes the profound brotherhood, sense of community, and the successful magical outcome of the Conclave, proving Setians can achieve great things through concerted effort.

A concise, profound statement defining 'Ipsissimus' as the unquestionable, secret supremacy of one's own being. It emphasizes that this state requires no external validation, advertisement, or public celebration, existing as an internal, known truth held dear by 'super-beings'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [17] We Know that We are a Temple
structure_content.summary: A summary of Ipsissimus Michael Aquino's insights during an informal meeting, where he discussed the evolving presence of Setians and the Temple's role as a tool for magical interaction. He recounts his personal history and philosophical journey, defining the Temple of Set as a 'prolonged, scientific approach to a sacred philosophy' focused on individual Setian growth rather than conventional religion or expansion based on quantity.

A short, poetic declaration affirming the unbreakable, 'unholy link of the knowing' that spiritually connects all Initiates of the Temple of Set, fostering a sense of unity, trust, and shared purpose among them.

This article elaborates on the First Foundation (1F), drawing parallels to Isaac Asimov's concept. It defines 1F's mission as futures research and contingency planning to ensure the Temple's survival and 'Setamorphosis' by monitoring key factors like energy, economics, politics, technology, and social phenomena. It outlines 1F's intelligence process and advisory role within the Temple's check-and-balance system, emphasizing its 'mundane' and 'Satanic lesser-magical' function.

structure_content.chapter_title: [20] All Nine Councillors Meet in One Place
structure_content.summary: A report on the historic first meeting of the Council of Nine as a complete unit during Set-I. Discussions covered future directions, the approval of a membership fee increase from $15 to $25, and the selection of a new Council insignia, noting the profound impact of their collective presence.

key_concepts.definition: A unique, superlative initiatory state of being within the Temple of Set, meaning 'His very own self' or 'he who is himself the most.' It signifies an ultimate, personal evolution to 'true divinity,' independent of external validation, and is recognized rather than bestowed.

A peculiar metapsychological, evolutionary process that represents the individual's transformation and growth within the Setian philosophy. The First Foundation is designed to ensure the survival of the Temple and its Initiates through this process.

Mental constructs that exist and are sustained by energy from human beings. The Temple of Set distinguishes between Set (existing intrinsically with its own power) and 'God' (a solely human-created entity dependent on human mental energy), asserting Setians' higher evolutionary order and potent individual magical power in sustaining the Set-entity.

A core Setian concept meaning 'to come into being,' 'to become,' or 'to transform.' It is linked to individual magical evolution and the continuous process of self-creation and awakening, as expressed in 'Xeper ir Xem.'

A Temple task force dedicated to futures research, intelligence collection, and contingency planning. Its primary mission is to predict future social, scientific, and environmental conditions to formulate strategies for the Temple and its Initiates' survival and continued evolution (Setamorphosis).
The 'unseen, unholy link of the knowing' that spiritually connects all Initiates of the Temple of Set, fostering a sense of unity, trust, and shared purpose among them.
Described as a 'crystal city, portal of dreams' and a spiritual location, it represents a foundational or sacred space for Setians, intrinsically linked to their identity and shared experience.

A symbol within Setianism that represents 'the principle of abstract beauty,' and when inverted, 'dualism, differentiation, or tension.' It is also ceremonially used, such as on the Ipsissimus medallion, symbolizing a microcosmic ritual chamber.

practical_system.description: The Temple of Set operates as a structured system designed to facilitate individual magical evolution, termed 'Setamorphosis,' through the development of unique intelligence and direct communion with the 'Set-entity.' This system is hierarchical, based on a degree structure (I°, II°, III°+, IV°, VI°) signifying progressive initiatory states and levels of magical expertise. The organization provides a framework for 'greater and lesser magic,' emphasizing 'right-brain activity' and personal transformation rather than external worship. Communal events like Conclaves and specific 'workings' (rituals) are crucial for fostering 'the Bond' among Initiates and strengthening the collective magical purpose. Strategic initiatives, such as the First Foundation, are employed for intelligence gathering and contingency planning to ensure the Temple's survival and the Setian evolutionary path.
tools: Medallions (e.g., gold disc with sterling silver pentagram for Ipsissimus)
Temple publications (The Scroll, Onyx Tablet, Ruby Tablet, Crystal Tablet)
Ritual grounds and shrines (e.g., at XemSet with decorated thrones, altars, open pentagrams, torches)
Computers and formatted reporting systems (for First Foundation data processing)
rituals: Set-I International Conclave Workings (e.g., III°+ working at XemSet, I°/II° ritual, all-member conclave ritual)
Recognition Ceremonies (e.g., Master of the Temple, Ipsissimus, Priest of Set III°)
Night outdoor working for consecrating shrines and ritual grounds (XemSet)

relevant_quotes.text: 'A major step in the evolution of the Temple of Set as a whole, something that has been a long time in the coming, something we all felt instinctively was vital, has been accomplished,' stated Magus Ronald K. Barrett, High Priest, during an interview following the conclusion of Set-I, held in Windsor, Canada July 12-15, XIV.

'For myself the degree of Ipsissimus is an initiatory state of being that is very personal. No matter what you do, no matter where you go, whom you know, what success or failure you experience - that part of yourself you bring out through being, becoming - the thing called 'initiation' - makes a difference in you, not as an animal but as an intelligence unique in the universe. 'This is true divinity.'

'Initiates, normally scattered and isolated throughout various parts of the continent, had the opportunity to experience, in rituals, the essential, magical core which is, of course, communication with the Set-entity.'

'The Temple of Set is a prolonged, scientific approach to a sacred philosophy. It is an infinitely precious view. Be careful how you use the word 'religion'. Much time can be wasted in dialogue due to the religious stereotypes which will be applied by ignorant minds.'
'The Temple is essentially a tool to help us interact with one another and cooperate in greater and lesser magic. The sacred 'focus' within the Temple is the individual Setian.'

'Since Set exists in a real sense and God doesn't, a discussion of the relative power of the two entities borders on the absurd, but this argument would not sway many non-Setians. They would probably believe that the number of human minds that sustain the entity as an image would determine its power. This is not the case however.'

'The Bond has been forged that is one and unbreakable. We, the beloved, have been joined by the unseen, unholy link of the knowing. All are linked by the Bond. All are of Set. All are gods and goddesses incarnate. Hail keepers of the unholy Flame! Keepers and forgers of the Bond. Set hails you as passers of the Flame. Hail Set, Prince of Darkness!'

critical_analysis.relevance: This publication provides a foundational insight into the early development, internal dynamics, and core philosophical tenets of the Temple of Set during a pivotal period. It demonstrates the emphasis on individual magical evolution (Xeper), the role of collective gatherings (Conclaves) in fostering group identity and magical synergy, and the strategic foresight embodied in initiatives like the First Foundation. For scholars of Western Esotericism and New Religious Movements, it offers primary documentation on the institutionalization of a modern occult order and its unique approach to divinity, self-actualization, and engagement with the mundane world.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience consists of current Initiates and prospective members of the Temple of Set, particularly those interested in its governance, philosophical depth, magical practices, and strategic objectives. It serves as an internal communication, education, and motivational tool. Additionally, it is highly relevant for academic researchers, historians, and practitioners studying Setianism, modern Satanism, and the evolution of contemporary magical orders.
